thread.title: Obama On B.B. King: 'The Blues Has Lost Its King, And America Has Lost A Legend'
thread.title_full: Obama On B.B. King: 'The Blues Has Lost Its King, And America Has Lost A Legend'

title: Obama On B.B. King: 'The Blues Has Lost Its King, And America Has Lost A Legend'
text: Notable People We've Lost In 2015 of   Prolific crime and mystery writer Ruth Rendell, perhaps best known for her Chief Inspector Wexford novels, died on May 2, 2015. She was 85. Jean Nidetch, the founder of Weight Watchers, died on April 29, 2015. She was 91. Andrew Lesnie, the Oscar-winning cinematographer who spent more than a decade collaborating with director Peter Jackson on the six "Lord of the Rings"and "Hobbit" films, died on April 27, 2015 at 59. Actress Jayne Meadows Cotter, who took turns lighting up the stage as well as the small and silver screens during her five-decade career, died on April 26, 2015. She was 95. M.H. Abrams, an esteemed critic, teacher and tastemaker who helped shape the modern literary canon as founding editor of the Norton Anthology of English Literature, died on April 21, 2015. He was 102. The Rev. Gardner C. Taylor, widely considered the dean of the nation’s black preachers and “the poet laureate of American Protestantism,” died on April 5, 2015. He was 96. Sarah Brady, 73, who became a tireless gun control activist after her husband, White House press secretary James S. Brady, was shot in the attempted assassination of President Reagan in 1981, died on April 3, 2015. The Rev. Robert H. Schuller, host of the "Hour of Power," who beamed his upbeat messages on faith and redemption to millions of followers from his landmark Crystal Cathedral only to see his empire crumble in his waning years, died on April 2, 2015. He was 88. Nancy Randolph Davis, a prominent Oklahoma civil rights activist who in 1949 became the first African-American to enroll at then segregated Oklahoma State University, died on March 23, 2015 at the age of 88. Swiss artist Hans Erni, who produced hundreds of paintings, sculptures, lithographs, engravings, etchings and ceramics, died on March 21, 2015. He was 106. Lee Kuan Yew, Singapore’s first prime minister, died on March 23, 2015 at the age of 91. Former Australian prime minister Malcolm Fraser died on March 20, 2015. He was 84. Terry Pratchett, author of the beloved Discworld fantasy series, died on March 12, 2015 at the age of 66, after battling Alzheimer's disease for many years. The Rev. Willie T. Barrow, a front-line civil rights fighter for decades and a mentor to younger generations of activists, died on March 12, 2015. She was 90. Richard Glatzer, who wrote and directed the film "Still Alice" while battling ALS, died on March 10, 2015. He was 63 Nine-time Emmy winner Sam Simon, who wrote episodes of “Taxi,” “Cheers” and “It’s Garry Shandling’s Show” before co-creating "The Simpsons," died on March 9, 2015. He was 59. Cardinal Edward M. Egan, the former Archbishop of New York and one of America's most prominent Catholic leaders, died on March 5, 2015. He was 82. Minnie Minoso, who hit a two-run home run in his first at-bat when he became major league baseball's first black player in Chicago in 1951, died on March 1, 2015. He was 92. CORRECTION: Caption has been updated to note Minoso was the MLB's first black player in Chicago. Anthony Mason, the rugged power forward who was a defensive force in the NBA from the 1990s into the early 21st century, died on Feb. 28, 2015. He was 48. Actor Leonard Nimoy, who was best-known for his role as Mr. Spock in the "Star Trek" franchise, died on Feb. 27, 2015. He was 83. Earl Lloyd, the first black player in NBA history, died on Feb. 27, 2015. He was 86. Legendary jazz musician Clark Terry, who mentored Miles Davis and Quincy Jones and played in the orchestras of both Count Basie and Duke Ellington and on "The Tonight Show," died on Feb. 21, 2015. He was 94. Jerome Kersey, the versatile small forward who helped the Portland Trail Blazers reach two NBA Finals and won a title with the San Antonio Spurs in 1999, died on Feb. 18, 2015 at 52. Singer-songwriter Lesley Gore, who topped the charts in 1963 at age 16 with her epic song of teenage angst, "It's My Party," and followed it up with the hits "Judy's Turn to Cry," and the feminist anthem "You Don't Own Me," died on Feb. 16, 2015. She was 68. Michele Ferrero, Italy's richest man and the owner of the global chocolate and confectionery empire behind Nutella, died on Feb. 14, 2015 at 89. Philip Levine, a Pulitzer Prize-winning poet whose intimate portraits of blue-collar life were grounded in personal experience and political conscience, died on Feb. 14, 2015. Levine was 87. New York Times columnist David Carr, one of the most incisive and influential writers on the media, died on Feb. 12 after collapsing in the newsroom. He was 58. CBS News' "60 Minutes" correspondent and foreign reporter Bob Simon died on Feb. 11 at the age of 73 from injuries sustained in a car accident. Hall of Fame coach Jerry Tarkanian, who built a basketball dynasty at UNLV but was defined more by his decades-long battle with the NCAA, died on Feb. 11, 2015. He was 84. Ed Sabol, the NFL Films founder who revolutionized sports broadcasting and re-imagined pro football from an up-and-coming league to must-watch theater, died on Feb. 9, 2015. He was 98. Dean Smith, the Hall of Fame innovator who won two national championships at North Carolina along with an Olympic gold medal while coaching some of the game's biggest names like Michael Jordan, died on Feb. 7, 2015. He was 83. Billy Casper, one of the most prolific winners on the PGA Tour, died on Feb. 7, 2015 at 83. Charlie Sifford, who broke the color barrier in golf as the first PGA Tour member, died on Feb. 3, 2015. He was 92. Colleen McCullough, 77, neuroscientist and author of the bestselling book "The Thorn Birds," died on Jan. 29, 2015. Dr. Charles Townes, who shared the 1964 Nobel Prize in Physics for the invention of the laser, died on Jan. 27, 2015. He was 99. Pioneering radio and TV host Joe Franklin, who gave breaks to the likes of Al Pacino and Bill Cosby on his variety show long before they became famous and who boasted he never missed a broadcast in decades, died on Jan. 24, 2015 at age 88. Ernie "Mr. Cub" Banks, the Cubs' first African-American player who went on to become an 11-time All-Star and two-time National League Most Valuable Player (1958-59), died on Jan. 23, 2015. He was 83. Saudi Arabia's King Abdullah, the powerful U.S. ally who fought against al-Qaida and sought to modernize the ultraconservative Muslim kingdom, died on Jan. 23, 2015. He was 90. Tony Verna, a television director and producer who invented instant replay for live sports games 51 years ago, died on Jan. 19, 2015. He was 81. Samuel Goldwyn Jr., the son of a fiercely independent-minded Hollywood mogul and the producer of many independent films in his own right including “Mystic Pizza” and studio hits including “Master and Commander,” died on Jan. 9, 2015. He was 88. Stuart Scott, one of the most recognizable anchors in ESPN "Sportscenter" history, died on Jan. 4, 2015 of cancer at the age of 49. Former U.S. Sen. Edward W. Brooke, a liberal Republican who became the first black in U.S. history to win popular election to the Senate, died on Jan. 3, 2015. He was 95. Former New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, the longest-serving Democratic governor in state history, died on Jan. 1, 2015. He was 82. Vince Camuto, legendary women’s footwear designer, died on Jan. 21, 2015. He was 78.  Share
